sections.content:
The primary requirements for study submission to MetaboLights are as follows;

1) MetaboLights user account.

2) Raw data to submit ie. spectral files produced by the instrument used for analysis or an open source version.
(This does not need to be added straight away but will be required to be uploaded before the study can be publish).

3) Study metadata as per the provided template when creating a study.
You can create an account by selecting Login above or via Create account.

When creating your MetaboLights account your email address will be your user name. Please contact us directly if you need to update this at any time.

You can also link your ORCID account, allowing you to claim your data submissions in your research achievements.
What is ORCID?

If you have problems accessing your account, please check your email (junk folder also!) for a confirmation.
Alternatively, contact us directly at MetaboLights Help.
</br>Overview of the 4 stages in the study submission process.

Submitting a study for curation

Once you have completed the study metadata, uploaded raw data files and the study successfully validates, select the status bar at the top of your study and change to curation. You will no longer be able to directly edit your study, please contact MetaboLights Help if you need to make further amendments.
You will also be prompted to set the public release date for your study, please note this is automatically set to a minimum of 4 weeks to allow for the curation process.

Following successful curation, the status will be updated to review and a private edit only link will be available on your study page for you to share with journal editors, collaborators etc if requested.
Once the release date is reached the study will become public. You can update this date at any stage by contacting MetaboLights Help.
Select Submit study followed by Create online to be guided through the study creation steps.

Submitters and authors
The submitter is the person who creates the study. They will be able to directly view & edit the study during the submission process and all correspondence will be direct to them. They will also be the main contact once the study is public. Authors are added as for a manuscript etc but will not have edit or private access to the study. If you would like edit rights to be given to collaborators they will also need to create an account. The submitter should then contact us to ask for further accounts to be added to the study. Group or project email addresses can be used to allow shared access to edit a study and link studies more readily in searches.

Access an existing study by selecting Submit study followed by Update now.
Alternatively use the url assigned when your study was created (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/metabolights/MTBLSXXX).
</br>This will take you to your study list where you can select the study of interest to edit.
</br><i>You can switch between the study overview and guided submission to edit your study using the tab in the bottom right corner of your study.

To progress the study to the next stage any validation errors must be resolved. Validation errors are evident in the information bar at the top of the study (if nothing is displayed the study has passed validation).

Further information is available in the Study Validations tab. There are 4 validation flags which can be viewed individually by selecting the drop-down menu. This includes successful, information, warning, error. You must address all errors and should also address warnings where applicable to progress your study.

Study accession number

Each new MetaboLights study is automatically assigned an accession number eg. MTBLS1. This is a permanent unique identifier and should be used to reference the study in manuscripts and other communications.

Where to find a study accession number

When you first create a new study you will be provided with information about the study unique identifier as shown below. You will also receive this information by email.
You can also see a list of all your studies & their unique identifiers on your My Studies page.

What to include in a manuscript

Permanent unique identifier; MTBLSxxxx.
Public url for your metabolomics study https://www.ebi.ac.uk/metabolights/MTBLSxxxx.
You may also wish to cite the MetaboLights reference Haug et al.

<u>A journal has requested access to my study</u></br></br>Once a study has been completed & the status updated to review, a private read-only link will be available at the top of your study page to share with the journal.
You can create an account by selecting Login above and Create a new account.
</br>When creating your MetaboLights account your email address will be your user name.

If you have problems accessing your account for the first time, please check your email (junk folder also!) for a confirmation.
Alternatively, contact us MetaboLights Help.

Your email address will be your user name. Please contact us directly at MetaboLights Help if you need to update this at any time.

To rest a password simply click the forgot your password link on the login page.

You can link MetaboLights account to your ORCID account, allowing you to claim your data submissions as part of your research achievements.

What is ORCID?

Your My Studies page provides an overview of all studies you have created in MetaboLights.

  • (a) Select to view all studies or studies with a particular status
  • (b) View basic outline information for each study including accession number, title, status, release date
  • (c) Choose to edit a study using Guided submission or Online editor tools
  • (d) View the submission tutorial video
  • (e) Create a new study

</br>When you create a study the Guided submission process will take you through the setup step-by-step. It will guide you through raw and sample data upload, creating assays and provide you with controlled vocabulary/ontology options in relevant fields. If you don’t have all the information to hand, don’t worry! You can access and edit your entire study at any time when in submission from your My Studies page.</br></br>Each MetaboLights study has 4 main sections, study description, sample, assay and metabolite information. The basic outlines for each are given below. Each section also corresponds to a specific file as indicated in which the information is stored.

sections.title: Study description (i_MTBLSxxx.txt)
sections.content: The study description should easily inform the reader about the study content and contacts.

img.description: (a) Study identifier & title (b) Author information (c) Abstract (d) Publication link (e) Keywords(f) Protocol text
(a) Study identifier & title (b) Author information (c) Abstract (d) Publication link (e) Keywords(f) Protocol text

sections.title: Sample information (s_MTBLSxxx.txt)
sections.content:
The sample information should provide all relevant facts about each sample and any controls / standards included in the study. There is ONE sample sheet per study.
Sample metadata should include a unique sample name, organism, organism part (for controls use eg. experimental blank and solvent) and sample type (ie. control, QC, experimental sample). Further sample descriptors should be included where available by selecting +Factor to add new columns (eg. Gender, Age, Treatment).

sections.title: Assay information (a_MTBLSxxx.txt)
sections.content: The assay information will describe the assay process for each control and sample in the assay and connect the sample name to both its corresponding raw data file and metabolite identification table. MULTIPLE assays can be added per study.</br></br>The assay is divided into sections each starting with a Protocol Ref column, eg. Chromatography, which describes the specifics of that part of the assay using controlled vocabulary, so every study using the same system is easily findable.</br></br>

sections.title: Metabolite information (m_MTBLSxxx.tsv)
sections.content: Each assay has a corresponding metabolite table. If results are cumulative of multiple assays, use the metabolite assignment file column in the assay table to point all assays to the same m_MTBLSxxx.tsv file name.</br></br>The metabolite information should include all metabolites / unknowns / features identified within the study.

img.description: Overview current adopted metabolite standards (Schmanski EL et al. 2014)

create_edit.title: Create & edit studies
create_edit.description: Choosing the option to Submit Study will take you to a login screen and then to your My Studies page. From there you can create a new study or edit an existing study.

sections.title: Create a new study
sections.content:
Creating a new study will take you to the Guided submission portal.
A new study will be automatically generated with a unique accession number / study identifier.
The study will also be added to your My Studies page. You can then follow the steps to add information to your study.
*You can exit the guided submission at any time and the information you have added will be automatically saved. To re-enter the study in Guided submission mode, simply go to My studies and select the Guided submission option below the study information.

sections.title: Edit existing study
sections.content:
All studies can be edited directly online. There are 2 ways to enter the edit mode;
In My Studies page select the Study overview option below the study information. *This is also available from the Guided submission mode, look for the pop-out option in the bottom right corner.
Studies can be edited online or downloaded and edited in eg. Excel. It is important not to remove columns or alter column headers when editing as the format is a fixed requirement. Additional columns can be added by choosing +factor, this should be done online before downloading files.
Some sections of metadata require ontology fields. When adding information using the online options, ontology options will appear as you type. If uploading a file without ontologies added, the online editor will prompt you to select ontologies in the fields above the tables.

img.description: From your study page on the website, select the edit option

Add_raw_data.title: Add raw data
Add_raw_data.description: A primary requirement for a MetaboLights study is the inclusion of the raw data. Raw and data should be uploaded and each file linked to the appropriate study though the assay table.

sections.content:
Where do I find upload options?
When using the Guided submission you will be prompted to upload raw files. If you do not have these available at the time you can come back to the same stage of the guided submission from your My Studies page at a later time. Alternatively, you can use the upload option in the Files tab of your study in the Online editor view of your study.

There are 2 file upload methods;

(1) Aspera connect plugin (recommended)
Aspera is a plugin that is very simple to install in your browser. Select the Aspera Upload option and then Install the plugin. Aspera is a fast way of transferring files which also enables the user to stop the transfer, and later resume where you left off. If you see raw data files in the final upload with .aspx appended, the file upload may have paused. Please open Aspera connect on your computer to check the status of your upload and resume upload if necessary. If the upload has completed you can delete the .aspx appended files or contact us to do so. NB. You may need to contact your local IT support if you do not have privileges to install browser plugins.

(2) FTP
FTP can be used on any computer, either directly from the command line or through a graphical user interface. However, on most computers, you have to install an FTP client first. If you are not familiar with using FTP from the command line, we can recommend the free FileZilla tool. Please see the FAQ section on the FileZilla pages for specific details about how this software works.

Accepted raw file formats
eg. .raw, .d, .cdf, open source formats (.mzML, .nmrML)

I can't see my files
If you have uploaded files but do not see them in your study folder, please try the copy to study folder option on the uploaded files tab and then refresh the page. If this is not successful please contact MetaboLights-help.

sections.title: Protocol
sections.content: When you set up an assay the required protocol fields are automatically generated, these must be completed using the Edit Description option and cannot be deleted or renamed.
You can add further protocol sections which can be edited, named and also deleted.
Within each protocol section there will be formatting options available as below.

sections.title: Ontologies
sections.content: Where possible terms are supported by controlled vocabularies / ontologies. Simply start to type and if available, options will appear below and you can select the appropriate term. If the term you are looking for does not appear, simply press enter and the text to add it as free text.
Where ontologies have not been added within tables a section will appear above the table to highlight terms. Simply click edit option to add on.

A study must pass validation to be progressed to the curation stage. If the validations have been unsuccessful this will appear at the top of the study. Further information can then be found in the Study Validations tab.

Within the validations tab you can select to view the different validation levels.
Each validation is listed according to the section it belongs to eg. publication, sample table, assay, files.
All errors must be resolved to progress. Please contact us if you need assistance to resolve an error.

Study title should summarize your study. A good title contains the fewest possible words that adequately describe the contents and/or purpose of your research. It is recommended to use the same title as the first publication.

sections.title: Add Study title
sections.content: You can add the title when you create a new study through guided submission or in the full study overview.

img.description: Add a title in the guided submission
Add a title in full study view

sections.title: Update study title
sections.content: You can modify the study title by clicking on it, or use your publication title to update.

img.description: update study title with online editor

video.description: change study title from the publication details

sections.title: Validation Rules:
sections.content: • - Study title should be at least 8 characters long.

MataboLights APIs - You can update the title of your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights study title API - GET, PUT using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

sections.title: Change email ID
sections.content: Please contact us directly at MetaboLights Help if you need to update your email ID at any time.

sections.title: Change submitter/study owner
sections.content:
The submitter is the person who creates the study. They will be able to directly view & edit the study during the submission process and all correspondence will be direct to them. They will also be the main contact once the study is public.
You can change the study ownership to your colleague. They should create a MetaboLights account and then you can make him/her as study submitter

sections.title: Give collaborators edit access to the study
sections.content: Authors are added as for a manuscript editor but will not have edit or private access to the study. If you would like edit rights to be given to collaborators they will also need to create an account.  The submitter can then contact us to ask for them to be added to the study. Group or project email addresses can be used to allow shared access to edit a study and link studies more readily.

sections.title: Import authers from the publication
sections.content: You also can import authers from the publication:

sections.title: Personal API token
sections.content: If you want to use the MetaboLights web service, you could find your personal API token from my account.

sections.title: GDPR
sections.content:
The 25th May 2018 marks the introduction across Europe of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). This is the first European wide change in data handling legislation 1995. Current legislation varies from country to country which leads to differences as to how data was handled. The GDPR needs no national legislation and provides a consistent framework across Europe as to how data must be handled.

Since the GDPR regulations came into effect in May 2018 we have not observed significant changes in the submissions of human studies, many of which are urine, blood or tissue based. Within a submission, there are varying levels of data requirement. Our primary requirement is the raw data set and, where we encourage as complete corresponding metadata as possible for the purposes of reanalysis, our basic requirement would involve only the accompanying organism and organism part. Further information regarding the submission process can be viewed on our help page and the institute's data protection policy can be found here.

In response to the wider metabolomics profile ethical debate and its increasing importance in clinical research, we are developing a controlled access version of MetaboLights. This will allow researchers to submit more restricted data which will then be available to others through ethics board approval, however, this will not be in place until 2021 at the earliest. This will follow the model of the already existing European Genome-Phenome Archive (Submission FAQs and GDPR notice).

Find more about EBI GDPR policy.

sections.title: Validation rules
sections.content:
• - The last name/surname should be at least 2 characters long.
  • - The first name should be at least 2 characters long.

MataboLights APIs - You can add/delete submitters for your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights submitter API - POST, DELETE using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.

MataboLights APIs - You can get/add/update/delete contacts for your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights contacts API - GET, POST, PUT, DELETE using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

Study abstract should briefly summarize your study, including
1) The overall purpose of the study;
2)The basic design of the study;
3)Major findings or trends found as a result of your analysis;
4)A brief summary.
It is recommended to use the same abstract as the publication.

sections.title: Update Abstract from the publication
sections.content: Your MetaboLights study abstract can be updated to match your publication abstract.

sections.title: Formating abstract
sections.content: Within abstract editing section, there will be formatting options available as below.

sections.title: Validation rules
sections.content: • - The study abstract should be at least 60 characters long.

MataboLights APIs - You can get/update description of your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights description API - GET, PUT using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.
The publication information should match any associated manuscript, include title, abstract, authors and publication status.

sections.title: Add publication
sections.content: Please add your publication details by guided submission or study online editor. The study title, abstract and authors also can be imported using a publication DOI, PubMed or EuropePMC identifier.

video.description: add publication details in the guided submission
add publication details in full study view

sections.title: publication status
sections.content:
- In preparation: Publication in preparation before submitting to a journal.
- Submitted: Publication submitted to a journal.
- Preprint: publications that have URL/DOI for an online copy that can be viewed by anyone but is not the final version.
- Published: Publication published in a journal.

sections.title: Validation rules
sections.content:
• - The publication title should be at least 25 characters long.
  • - Provide a list of authors, separated by commas. As appears in the publication, do not include affiliation.
  • - Only provide the id number, not prefixed with PMID.
  • - Provide the publication status, this should be at least 5 characters long.

MataboLights APIs - You can get/add/update/delete publication information of your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights publication API - GET, POST, PUT, DELETE using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

Effective keywords for your study portray an accurate representation of what you publish. It also helps MetaboLights search to indexes the study. Keywords should:
- Represent the content of your manuscript
- Be specific to your field or sub-field

sections.title: Add keyword
sections.content: To add new keywords to your study, you can click the +Add in the keywords section. Type the keyword and use the drop-down to select the most relevant ontology term. If the input term can’t match to any of our ontology control vocabulary, type your plain text and press enter to accept (then OK to add to the keyword).

sections.title: Are there any limits on the number of keywords?
sections.content: We have no limit on the number of keywords.
Study Factors are key parameters within a study that differentiate samples into groups e.g. ‘ gene knockout’ , ‘gender ’, ‘ location ’, ‘ year ’, ‘ age ’, ‘ time elapsed ’ etc.

sections.title: Add a factor
sections.content: You can add study factors by clicking the +Add factor button in Factors section. Type the factor term and use the drop-down to select the most relevant ontology term. If there is no ontology term available, type your free text and press enter to accept (then OK to add to the factor).

sections.title: Check factor details
sections.content: You can check factor details by click the term in Factors section.

sections.title: Modify/Delete the factor
sections.content: You can modify/delete a factor by click the pencil sign.

sections.title: Add factor to the sample sheet
sections.content: You can add further columns to the sample sheet by selecting +factor.

sections.title: Delete factor from the sample sheet
sections.content: To delete the factor, you can download the sample file to remove the associated column(s) and re-upload the modified file.

sections.title: Validation rules
sections.content: • - The factor should be at least 5 characters long.

MataboLights APIs - You can get/add/update/delete factors of your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights factor API - GET, POST, PUT, DELETE using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

Protocols are central for reproducibility purposes; Metabolights keeps detailed descriptions of experiments in this section. includes:
1. Sample collection
2. Extraction
3. Chromatography/NMR sample
4. Mass spectrometry/NMR spectroscopy
5. Data transformation
6. Metabolite identification

sections.title: Validation rules
sections.content:
• - The protocol should be at least 40 characters long.
  • - The protocol name should be at least 8 characters long.
  • - All expected protocol should be defined.
  • - All characters should be printable in the protocol description, ie. non-UTF-8 compatible characters.

MataboLights APIs - You can get/add/update/delete protocol of your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights factor API - GET, POST, PUT, DELETE using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.

MataboLights APIs - You can get protocol and assay mappings for your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights factor API - GETusing our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

The sample information should provide all relevant facts about each sample and any controls/standards included in the study. There is ONE sample sheet per study. 
Sample metadata should include a unique sample name, organism, organism part (for controls use eg. experimental blank and solvent) and sample type (ie. control, QC, experimental sample). Further sample descriptors should be included where available by selecting +Factor to add new columns (eg. Gender, Age, Treatment)
Add a new sample

video.description: add publication details in full study view

sections.content: Edit a sample sheet cell

video.description: add publication details in full study view

sections.content: Edit a whole sample column

video.description: add publication details in full study view

sections.content: Delete a sample/row

video.description: add publication details in full study view

sections.title: Delete an added column
sections.content: To delete the added column, you can download the sample file to remove the associated column(s) and re-upload the modified file. It is important not to remove original columns came with the study or alter column headers when editing as the format is a fixed requirement.

sections.title: Validation Rules:
sections.content:
• - Sample columns present in the sample file.
  • - "Sample collection" column completely filled in.
  • - No empty rows in sample file.
  • - Organism name should be at least 5 characters long.
  • - Organism cannot be 'human' or 'man', please choose the 'Homo sapiens' taxonomy term.
  • - Organism cannot be one of the invalid terms.
Invalid organism term: cat, dog, mouse, horse, flower, man, fish, leave, root, mice, steam, bacteria, value, food, matrix, mus, rat, blood, urine, plasma, hair, fur, skin, saliva, fly, unknown.

MataboLights APIs - You can get a list of all sample names, mapped to files in the study and upload folder(s) programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights study sample API - GET using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.

MataboLights APIs - You can get Get ISA-Tab Sample file programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights study ISA-Tab sample API - GET using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

The assay information will describe the assay process for each control and sample in the assay and connect the sample name to both its corresponding raw data file and metabolite identification table. MULTIPLE assays can be added per study.

The assay is divided into sections each starting with a Protocol Ref column, eg. Chromatography, which describes the specifics of that part of the assay using controlled vocabulary, so every study using the same system is easily findable.

sections.title: Validation Rules:
sections.content:
• - At least one assay file in the study.
  • - All the referenced assay files can be found.
  • - No empty column names in the assay spreadsheet.
  • - Template columns in the relevant assay sheet can not be removed.
  • - Required columns can not be empty.
  • - Sample names that are all referenced in assays.
  • - Raw or Derived files existed in MS study.
  • - Derived, fid or acqu files existed in NMR study.
  • - Are there more sample rows than assay rows.
  • - Assay files are referenced of the correct type.

MataboLights APIs - You can get/add/delete assays of your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights study title API - GET, POST, DELETE using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.

MataboLights APIs - You can download assay file from your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights study title API - GET using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

Column Name Description Example
Sample Name A unique identifier from a particular source (a batch of samples can have a unique sample name but the same source name). It’s usually associated with an output spectral data filename. pas101220_104
Protocol REF - Extraction This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Extraction. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Extraction
Parameter Value - Extraction Method This how a sample was extracted from its source material. Methanol,400 µL water
Extract Name Leave blank if you don’t have one.
Protocol REF - NMR sample This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to NMR sample. This should be present in every sample row. NMR sample
Parameter Value - NMR tube type Size and type of tube. standard 5 mm glass NMR tube (Wilmad, LabGlass, USA)
Parameter Value - Solvent Solvent used in the NMR sample. D2O,CDCL3
Parameter Value - Sample pH Sample pH value. 7
Parameter Value - Temperature Sample Temperature value. 298
Unit With relevant temperature unit. Kelvin, Celsius
Labelled Extract Name Leave blank if you don’t have one.
Label If you used a chemical or biochemical marker in the sample such as a radioactive isotope of fluorescent dye which is bound to a material in order to make it detectable in an analytical instrument then enter it here. hydrogen molecular entity
Protocol REF - NMR spectroscopy This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to NMR spectroscopy. This should be present in every sample row. NMR spectroscopy
Parameter Value - Instrument Add the full name of the instrument you used for the NMR study in this assay, including the model number and its operating frequency Varian Unity Inova 500 MHz spectrometer
Parameter Value - NMR Probe Add a full description including the name and type of probe used.This information can be found in the ‘Acquisition Parameter Data File’, ‘acqus.txt’ found within the Bruker raw data file structure, in the field marked ‘ $PROBHD= ’. 5 mm CPTCI 1H-13C/15N/D Z-GRD,TRIPLE
Parameter Value - Number of transients The number of scans acquired. This information can be found in the ‘Acquisition Parameter Data File’, ‘acqus.txt’ found within the Bruker raw data file structure, in the field marked ‘$NS=’. 128
Parameter Value - Pulse sequence name The pulse sequence program used with a short description.This information can be found in the ‘Acquisition Parameter Data File’, ‘acqus.txt’ found within the Bruker raw data file structure, in the field marked ‘ $PULPROG= ’ and in the file ‘pulseprogram.txt’. 1D 1H with presaturation (presat)
Parameter Value - Magnetic field strength In Tesla (T) 11.7
Unit Units can be added in exactly the same way as Temperature unit column. Tesla
Acquisition Parameter Data File These should contain the acquisition parameter data. In the Bruker raw data file structure, the file is called ‘acqus.txt ’. acqus1.txt
Protocol REF - NMR assay This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to NMR assay. This should be present in every sample row. NMR assay
NMR Assay Name This can be, but doesn’t have to be, the same as the ‘Sample Name’ 17_QC1
Free Induction Decay Data File This is where you should enter, either the folder or the zipped NMR raw files for each sample in this study. 17_QC1.zip
Protocol REF Data transformation This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Data transformation. This should be present in every sample row. Data transformation
Normalization name These should contain the normalization data files. Total sum
Derived Spectral Data File If your data has been transformed into one of the open-source raw data formats e.g. JCAMP , nmrML , then add them here.Please add full path of the file in the cell 17_QC1.nmrML,DERIVED_FILES/17_QC1.nmrML
Protocol REF Metabolite identification This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Metabolite identification. This should be present in every sample row. Metabolite identification
Data Transformation Name These should contain the data transformation files
Metabolite Assignment File (MAF) A TSV file containing information about the metabolites investigated in the study. Information regarding database accession IDs , where in the spectra the metabolite is found and data pertaining to its abundance within the study samples should be in this file. m_mtbls1_NMR_spectroscopy_v2_maf.tsv
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

Column Name Description Example
Sample Name A unique identifier from a particular source (a batch of samples can have a unique sample name but the same source name). It’s usually associated with an output spectral data filename. ADG10003u_007
Protocol REF - Extraction This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Extraction. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Extraction
Parameter Value - Post Extraction This column describes how the sample was extracted into a solvent prior to being injected into the analytical instrument of choice. 400 µL water
Parameter Value - Derivatization If the sample has been subjected to chemical modification prior to injection. sylilation, acetylation, alkylation
Extract Name Leave blank if you don’t have one.
Protocol REF - Chromatography This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Chromatography. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Chromatography
Parameter Value - Chromatography Instrument Add the full name of the instrument you used for the Chromatographic part of this assay, including the manufacturer and model number as reported in manufacturer’s brochures, user manuals, or on their website. Shimadzu Nexera UHPLC system
Parameter Value - Column model Manufacturer, model number and dimensions. HSS T3 C18 (1.8 μm, 1.0 x 100 mm; Waters), Hypersil GOLD C18 (1.9 μm, 2.1 mm x 150 mm; Thermo Scientific),Discovery HS F5 (3 µm, 2.1 mm x 150 mm; Thermo Scientific)
Parameter Value - Column type Type or phase of column used. reverse phase,normal phase
Labelled Extract Name Leave blank if you don’t have one.
Label If you used a chemical or biochemical marker in the sample such as a radioactive isotope of fluorescent dye which is bound to a material in order to make it detectable in an analytical instrument then enter it here.
Protocol REF - Mass spectrometry This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Mass spectrometry. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Mass spectrometry
Parameter Value - Scan polarity Values should identical within each assay. If you have ‘positive’ or ‘negative’ values in the same assay then split them into separate ‘positive’ and ‘negative’ assays. positive, negative or alternating
Parameter Value - Scan m/z range The range used in the assay. 100-1000,MRM
Parameter Value - Instrument Add the full name of the mass spectrometer/detector you used for this LC/MS assay, including the instrument manufacturer and model number as reported in manufacturer’s brochures, user manuals, or on their website. Bruker micrOTOF-Q II, LTQ Orbitrap Discovery, Thermo Scientific Exactive
Parameter Value - Ion source Where applicable to the instrument. ESI
Parameter Value - Mass analyzer The analyser/detector of the mass fragments generated during the assay. Triple quadrupole
MS Assay Name This can be, but doesn’t have to be, the same as the ‘Sample Name’ treated 0 min rabbit 1, M1146_20h_1
Raw Spectral Data File This is where you should enter the Raw (unprocessed) MS data files (.RAW).Please add full path of the file in the cell. PFPP M1146_20h_1_063.lcd, /RAW_FILES/Sepd340.raw
Protocol REF - Data transformation This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Data transformation. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Data transformation
Normalization name these should contain the normalization data files preferably as an Excel spreadsheet file. If you don’t have these then leave the cells/column blank. MSpos-Ex1-Col0-48h-Ag_normalized_data.xlsx,MSpos-Ex1-Col0-48h-Ag_normalized_data.txt
Derived Spectral Data File If your data has been transformed into one of the open-source raw data formats e.g. mzML , CDF, or any other converted file, then add them here.Please add full path of the file in the cell. Sepd340.mzML,/DERIVED FILES/Sepd340.mzML
Protocol REF - Metabolite identification This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Metabolite identification. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Metabolite identification
Data Transformation Name These should contain the data transformation files.
Metabolite Assignment File (MAF) A TSV file containing information about the metabolites investigated in the study. Information regarding database accession IDs , where in the spectra the metabolite is found and data pertaining to its abundance within the study samples should be in this file. m_mtbls1_mass_spectrometry_v2_maf.tsv
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

Column Name Description Example
Sample Name A unique identifier from a particular source (a batch of samples can have a unique sample name but the same source name). It’s usually associated with an output spectral data filename.
Lva001
Protocol REF - Extraction This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Extraction. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Extraction
Parameter Value - Post Extraction This how the sample was extracted into a solvent prior to being injected into the analytical instrument of choice. 2 ml ethyl acetate
Parameter Value - Derivatization If the sample has been subjected to chemical modification prior to injection. sylilation, acetylation, alkylation, other
Extract Name Leave blank if you don’t have one.
Protocol REF - Chromatography This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Chromatography. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Chromatography
Parameter Value - Chromatography Instrument Add the full name of the instrument you used for the Chromatographic part of this assay, including the manufacturer and model number as reported in manufacturer’s brochures, user manuals, or on their website. Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 Ultra
Parameter Value - Column model Manufacturer, model number and dimensions in the format shown in the examples: Zebron ZB-AAA GC(10 m x 0.25 mm; Phenomenex), HP-5 GC (0.25 μm, 30 m x 0.320 mm; Agilent Technologies)
Parameter Value - Column type Polarity of column used. This information can be found on the manufacturer’s website. low polarity, medium polarity, or high polarity
Labelled Extract Name Leave blank if you don’t have one.
Label If you used a chemical or biochemical marker in the sample such as a radioactive isotope of fluorescent dye which is bound to a material in order to make it detectable in an analytical instrument then enter it here.
Protocol REF - Mass spectrometry This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Mass spectrometry. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Mass spectrometry
Parameter Value - Scan polarity This should be ‘positive’ for a GC/MS assay. positive
Parameter Value[Scan m/z range] The range used in the assay. 50-400,35-500
Parameter Value - Instrument Add the full name of the mass spectrometer/detector you used for this GC/MS assay, including the instrument manufacturer and model number as reported in manufacturer’s brochures, user manuals, or on their website. Thermo Electron Trace DSQ quadrupole, Agilent 5975C MSD, LECO Pegasus 4D, Waters GCT Premier
Parameter Value - Ion source Where applicable to the instrument. electron ionization
Parameter Value - Mass analyzer The analyser/detector of the mass fragments generated during the assay, quadrupole
MS Assay Name This can be, but doesn’t have to be, the same as the ‘Sample Name’ S1-4528-S17
Raw Spectral Data File This is where you should enter the Raw (unprocessed) MS data files (.RAW ). Please add full path of the file in the cell. S1-4528-S17.CDF,/RAW_FILES/S1-4528-S17.CDF
Protocol REF - Data transformation This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Data transformation. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Data transformation
Normalization name These should contain the normalization data files preferably as an Excel spreadsheet file. If you don’t have these then leave the cells/column blank.. WHELP-GCMS.xlsx,WHELP-GCMS.txt
Derived Spectral Data File If your data has been transformed into one of the open-source raw data formats e.g. mzML , CDF, or any other converted file, then add them here. Please add full path of the file in the cell. Sepd340.mzML, /DERIVED FILES/Sepd340.mzML
Protocol REF - Metabolite identification This is the column marking the start of data pertaining to Metabolite identification. The example term MUST be present in all rows of this column. Metabolite identification
Data Transformation Name These should contain the data transformation files.
Metabolite Assignment File (MAF) A TSV file containing information about the metabolites investigated in the study. Information regarding database accession IDs , where in the spectra the metabolite is found and data pertaining to its abundance within the study samples should be in this file. m_whelp_metabolite_profiling_mass_spectrometry-1_v2_maf.tsv
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

Each assay has a corresponding metabolite table (referenced in the metabolite assignment file column). When you created your assay a corresponding metabolite annotation file will add to your study and referenced automatically (m_MTBLSxxx.tsv). The metabolite information should include all metabolites / unknowns / features identified within the study.
If results are cumulative of multiple assays, use the metabolite assignment file column in the assay table to point all assays to the same m_MTBLSxxx.tsv file name.

sections.title: Validation Rules:
sections.content:
• - MAF can not be empty.
  • - All MAF should be referenced in the assay.
  • - MAF file should readable.
  • - "database_identifier" should be the first column.
  • - Columns 'database_identifier', 'chemical_formula', 'smiles', 'inchi' and 'metabolite_identification' found in the correct column position.
  • - MS/NMR assay name can be found in the MAF.
  • - Sample name can be found in the MAF.
  • - No empty rows in the MAF.

MataboLights APIs - You can update the title of your study programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights study title API - GET, PUT using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.
Can't find what you are looking for? Check out our FAQ's for most commonly asked questions and solutions.

When using the Guided submission you will be prompted to upload raw files. If you do not have these available at the time you can come back to the same stage of the guided submission from your My Studies page at a later time. Alternatively, you can use the upload option in the Files tab of your study in the Online editor view of your study.

There are 2 file upload methods;

sections.title: 1. Aspera connect plugin (recommended)
sections.content: Aspera is a plugin that is very simple to install in your browser. Select the Aspera Upload option and then Install the plugin. Aspera is a fast way of transferring files which also enables the user to stop the transfer, and later resume where you left off.

If you see raw data files in the final upload with .aspx appended, the file upload may have paused. Please open Aspera connect on your computer to check the status of your upload and resume upload if necessary. If the upload has completed you can delete the .aspx appended files or contact us to do so. NB. You may need to contact your local IT support if you do not have privileges to install browser plugins.

sections.title: 2. FTP
sections.content:
FTP can be used on any computer, either directly from the command line or through a graphical user interface. However, on most computers, you have to install an FTP client first. If you are not familiar with using FTP from the command line, we can recommend the free FileZilla tool.

You willl receive a email when you request a upload folder for your study, including FTP setting parameters:
user: mtblight
password: ****
server: ftp-private.ebi.ac.uk
remote folder: /prod/<your studyID>-obfuscation_code

Please be aware the remote folder needs to be entirely typed, as the folder is not browsable. So use "cd /prod/<your studyID>-obfuscation_code" to access your private folder.

sections.title: Upload file to a subfolder
sections.content: You need to organise files locally in the same folder structure and then upload. This would automatically add it to the corresponding folders in the study.

Download.title: Download
Download.description: Studies can be edited online or downloaded and edited in eg. Excel. There are three file download methods;

sections.title: 2. Aspera download
sections.content: To download Public study, you can use Aspera download in the file section.

sections.title: 3. API download
sections.content:
You can view/download files by using our web service: typing https://www.ebi.ac.uk/metabolights/ws/studies/<studyid>/<filename> to your browser address bar.

MataboLights APIs - You also can get Get ISA-Tab Investigation/Assay/Sample files programmatically using our APIs.
Try the MetaboLights study ISA-Tab sample API. - GET_Investigation, GET_Assay , GET_Sample using our swagger interface.
Please note that you would need an active MetaboLights account and API Key to access the API.

sections.title: Accepted Derived / raw file formats
sections.content:
Derived file formats: mzml, nmrml, mzxml, xml, mzdata, cef, cnx, peakml, xy, smp, scan
Raw file formats: d, raw, idb, cdf, wiff, scan, dat, cmp, cdf.cmp, lcd, abf, jpf, xps, mgf

sections.title: > What is the difference between FTP and Aspera?
sections.content: FTP, or File Transfer Protocol, is a standard network protocol for exchanging files across the internet. Aspera is a faster alternative to FTP and provides greater user control enabling individual transfer rates and bandwidth sharing to be set.

sections.title: > Failed to open TCP connection for SSH error while using Aspera
sections.content:
This error was due to your firewall settings, which is preventing the Aspera connect plugin from connecting to our servers. Please make sure that your firewall isn’t blocking request to our servers. (Remote host: hx-fasp-1.ebi.ac.uk / fasp.ebi.ac.uk, Port: 33001) and run the diagnosis Aspera test-connect.

If the problem still persists, please contact us at metabolights-help@ebi.ac.uk, along with your Aspera log files.
Where can I find Aspera log files?

Typically, consumer and business firewalls allow direct outbound connections from client computers on TCP and UDP. There is no configuration required for Aspera transfers in this case. In the special case of firewalls disallowing direct outbound connections, typically using proxy servers for Web browsing, the following configuration applies:
- Allow outbound connections from the Aspera client on the TCP port (TCP/33001, by default, when connecting to a Windows server, or on another non-default port for other server operating systems).
- Allow outbound connections from the Aspera client on the fasp UDP port (33001, by default).
- If you have a local firewall on your server (like Windows Firewall), verify that it is not blocking your SSH and fasp transfer ports (e.g. TCP/UDP 33001).

sections.title: > How to use FTP uploader (e.g. FileZilla)
sections.content:
You willl receive a email when you request a upload folder for your study, including:
user: mtblight
password: ****
server: ftp-private.ebi.ac.uk
remote folder: /prod/<your studyID>-obfuscation_code

Please be aware the remote folder needs to be entirely typed, as the folder is not browsable. So use "cd /prod/<your studyID>-obfuscation_code" to access your private folder. For example with FileZilla:

sections.title: > Can I upload a compressed file (*.zip)?
sections.content: If your data is huge, compression definitely helps especially if you are using FTP. We are okay with both compressed or uncompressed RAW files. If you upload compressed .zip files, please let us know when you have finished uploading all your files. We will then unzip them for you.

sections.title: > Error: Insufficient permissions?
sections.content: Please contact us at metabolights-help@ebi.ac.uk to resolve this issue.

sections.title: > Error: Insufficient permissions
sections.content: Please contact us directly at MetaboLights Help to resolve this issue.

sections.title: > Error: No raw or derived files found in the assay
sections.content:
The online editor by default recognises and lists only the root level files/folders. Please organise your raw files and derived files in the subfolders and specify the full path in the assay sheets.
Example:
DERIVED_FILES/subfolder/file.mzml
RAW_FILES/subfolder/folder.d

sections.title: > Do you accept Excel format?
sections.content: We support metabolite identification information reported as tab-separated values (tsv file - ISA ) .

sections.title: > How can I move files from one folder to another?
sections.content: Please contact us at MetaboLights Help to let us move the files for you. Alternatively, you can delete the files and reupload again in the right folder location.

sections.title: > Can I upload self-defined folder to the study?
sections.content: You can structure the data in whatever the way you would like to in the study. We recommend you upload RAW files into the RAW_FILES folder and similarly Derived files into the DERIVED_FILES folder.

sections.title: >  How can I recover deleted files？
sections.content: Please contact us directly at MetaboLights Help, we will help you to restore the deleted files.

sections.title: > What is the difference between sample name and source name?
sections.content:
Source Name is a general name that reflects the origin of the samples, e.g urine or serum.
Sample Name is the most important element in the ISA-Tab structure that will link everything together. This should be a unique individual name to the sample that has been used throughout the study.

sections.title: > Error: All Raw and Derived Spectral Data Files are missing from assay.
sections.content: Please upload associate raw files and populate the 'RAW Spectral Data File' column with the names of the appropriate .raw file for the sample in your Assays.

sections.title: > What is the difference between "Raw Spectral Data File" and "Derived Spectral Data File"?
sections.content:
"Raw Spectral Data File” are the files directly from the analysis platform.
"Derived Spectral Data File” include opensource converted files (eg. your mzML) or any other derived file you may wish to include.

sections.title: > How can replicates be defined in the assay table?
sections.content: You could add an additional column to your assays called ‘replicate' which you might prefer to make a clear distinction that it is a replicate.

sections.title: > How can I add the columns to include the peak area of each metabolite identified per sample?
sections.content: Please download the MAF sheet, and edit it locally, e.g. Excel. You can add sample columns to the right end of the sheet and fill in the peak area values to the relevant sample columns in the relevant metabolite rows. Save and then re-upload MAF to your study.

sections.title: > Where are the units of the final entries in the maf file defined?
sections.content: The MAF table values are generally given as either direct reads from the analysis platform or values normalised to controls. There are no unit fields defined.

sections.title: > If we enter several retention times (for different batches which are defined in the sample table), can they all be entered in the retention time column of the maf file separated by slashes?
sections.content: You can add these as new rows if you want to specify the RT for each sample or separated with a pipeline “ | “.
